title: Quick Test 03: Word Order
description: Quick practice for German word order (main clauses, questions, subordinate clauses)

questions.explanationDetail: In main clauses, the conjugated verb is in position 2. Ich (1) gehe (2) heute ins Kino. Subject + verb + time + place. This is standard German word order.
When sentence starts with time/place, verb stays in position 2. Heute (1) gehe (2) ich ins Kino. This is called inversion: verb comes before subject.
In yes/no questions, verb comes first. Gehst (1) du (2) heute ins Kino? Verb + subject + rest. This is how to form questions without question words.
With question words (wann, wo, wie), verb is in position 2. Wann (1) gehst (2) du ins Kino? Question word + verb + subject. This is standard for W-questions.

questions.text: Ich weiß, dass du heute ins Kino ___.
questions.explanationDetail: After 'dass', verb goes to the end. Ich weiß, dass du heute ins Kino gehst. Subordinating conjunctions (dass, weil, wenn, als, obwohl) send verb to end.

questions.explanation: Perfekt: auxiliary in position 2, participle at end
questions.explanationDetail: In Perfekt, auxiliary verb (bin/habe) is in position 2, past participle at end. Ich bin gestern ins Kino gegangen. Gehen uses 'sein' in Perfekt.

questions.text: Ich kann heute nicht ins Kino ___.
questions.explanationDetail: With modal verbs, infinitive goes to the end. Ich kann heute nicht ins Kino gehen. Modal verb (kann) is conjugated in position 2, infinitive at end.

questions.text: Ich gehe ins Kino, weil ich einen Film sehen ___.
questions.explanation: Subordinate clause with modal: modal at end
questions.explanationDetail: In subordinate clause with modal verb, modal goes to end (after infinitive). Weil ich einen Film sehen will. Order: ... + infinitive + modal verb.
